lines.text: What is a digital signature?

spans.text: What is a digital signature?

lines.text: Digital signatures are a secure and efficient way to electronically sign and authenticate

spans.text: Digital signatures are a secure and efficient way to electronically sign and authenticate

lines.text: documents, ensuring their authenticity and integrity. By using digital signatures, you can sign

spans.text: documents, ensuring their authenticity and integrity. By using digital signatures, you can sign

lines.text: documents quickly and easily, and be confident that they can’t be tampered with or forged.

spans.text: documents quickly and easily, and be confident that they can’t be tampered with or forged.

lines.text: Why validate a digital signature?

spans.text: Why validate a digital signature?

lines.text: When you receive a signed document, you may want to validate its signature to verify the

spans.text: When you receive a signed document, you may want to validate its signature to verify the

lines.text: signer and the signed content. Depending on how you’ve configured your application,

spans.text: signer and the signed content. Depending on how you’ve configured your application,

lines.text: validation may occur automatically. Signature validity is determined by checking the

spans.text: validation may occur automatically. Signature validity is determined by checking the

lines.text: authenticity of the signature’s digital ID certificate status and document integrity.

spans.text: authenticity of the signature’s digital ID certificate status and document integrity.

lines.text: To verify authenticity, the validator checks if the signer's certificate or its parent certificates are

spans.text: To verify authenticity, the validator checks if the signer's certificate or its parent certificates are

lines.text: trusted. The validity of the signing certificate is also checked based on the user's Acrobat or

spans.text: trusted. The validity of the signing certificate is also checked based on the user's Acrobat or

lines.text: Acrobat Reader settings.

spans.text: Acrobat Reader settings.

lines.text: To verify document integrity, the validator checks if the signed content was altered after

spans.text: To verify document integrity, the validator checks if the signed content was altered after

lines.text: signing. If changes were made, the verification ensures that the signer allowed the changes.

spans.text: signing. If changes were made, the verification ensures that the signer allowed the changes.

lines.text: Certify a PDF

spans.text: Certify a PDF

lines.text: Certifying a PDF means approving its contents and specifying what changes are allowed for

spans.text: Certifying a PDF means approving its contents and specifying what changes are allowed for

lines.text: the document to remain certified. For example, a government agency creates a form with

spans.text: the document to remain certified. For example, a government agency creates a form with

lines.text: signature fields and certifies it, allowing users to only change form fields and sign the

spans.text: signature fields and certifies it, allowing users to only change form fields and sign the

lines.text: document. Removing pages or adding comments will result in losing the certified status.

spans.text: document. Removing pages or adding comments will result in losing the certified status.

lines.text: A certifying signature can only be applied if the PDF has no other signatures. These signatures

spans.text: A certifying signature can only be applied if the PDF has no other signatures. These signatures

lines.text: can be visible or invisible, and a blue ribbon icon in the Signatures panel confirms a valid

spans.text: can be visible or invisible, and a blue ribbon icon
in the Signatures panel confirms a valid

spans.text: certifying signature. Adding a certifying digital signature requires a digital ID.

spans.text: Sign component PDFs and PDF Portfolios

lines.text: You can sign component PDFs within a PDF Portfolio, or sign the PDF Portfolio as a whole.

spans.text: You can sign component PDFs within a PDF Portfolio, or sign the PDF Portfolio as a whole.

lines.text: Signing a component PDF locks the PDF for editing and secures its content. After signing all

spans.text: Signing a component PDF locks the PDF for editing and secures its content. After signing all

lines.text: the component PDFs, you can sign the entire PDF Portfolio to finalize it. Alternatively, you can

spans.text: the component PDFs, you can sign the entire PDF Portfolio to finalize it. Alternatively, you can

lines.text: sign the PDF Portfolio as a whole to lock the content of all component PDFs simultaneously.

spans.text: sign the PDF Portfolio as a whole to lock the content of all component PDFs simultaneously.

lines.text: XML data signatures

spans.text: XML data signatures

lines.text: Acrobat and Acrobat Reader support XML data signatures that are used to sign data in XML

spans.text: Acrobat and Acrobat Reader support XML data signatures that are used to sign data in XML

lines.text: Forms Architectures (XFA) forms. The form author provides XML signing, validating, or

spans.text: Forms Architectures (XFA) forms. The form author provides XML signing, validating, or

lines.text: clearing instructions for form events, such as button click, file save, or submit.

spans.text: clearing instructions for form events, such as button click, file save, or submit.

lines.text: XML data signatures conform to the W3C XML-Signature standard. Like PDF digital

spans.text: XML data signatures conform to the W3C XML-Signature standard. Like PDF digital

lines.text: signatures, XML digital signatures ensure integrity, authentication, and non-repudiation in

spans.text: signatures, XML digital signatures ensure integrity, authentication, and non-repudiation in

lines.text: documents.

spans.text: documents.

lines.text: However, PDF signatures have multiple data verification states. Some states are called when a

spans.text: However, PDF signatures have multiple data verification states. Some states are called when a

lines.text: user alters the PDF-signed content. In contrast, XML signatures only have two data verification

spans.text: user alters the PDF-signed content. In contrast, XML signatures only have two data verification

lines.text: states, valid and invalid. The invalid state is called when a user alters the XML-signed content.

spans.text: states, valid and invalid. The invalid state is called when a user alters the XML-signed content.

lines.text: Establish long-term signature validation

spans.text: Establish long-term signature validation

lines.text: Long-term signature validation allows you to verify the signature's validity long after the

spans.text: Long-term signature validation allows you to verify the signature's validity long after the

lines.text: document was signed. To achieve this, all the necessary elements for signature validation

spans.text: document was signed. To achieve this, all the necessary elements for signature validation

lines.text: must be embedded in the signed PDF. These elements can be embedded during the

spans.text: must be embedded in the signed PDF. These elements can be embedded during the

lines.text: document signing process or added afterward.

spans.text: When a certificate expires, the issuing authority is no longer responsible for providing
